p.text: In this Division, a cross-vesting Act means the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 or the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 of the Commonwealth.
Expressions used in this Division have, in relation to proceedings under a cross-vesting Act, the same meaning as in that Act.

In this Division, a reference to a provision of a cross-vesting Act is a reference to a provision of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987, and extends to the corresponding provision of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 of the Commonwealth.
Legislation cited in [44.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Federal Courts (State Jurisdiction) Act 1999.

The High Court's decision in Re Wakim; Ex parte McNally (1999) 198 CLR 511; 163 ALR 270; 31 ACSR 99 held that the cross-vesting laws were invalid in so far as they purported to confer state jurisdiction on federal courts. As a result of that decision the New South Wales Parliament enacted the Federal Courts (State Jurisdiction) Act 1999 . That legislation provided a mechanism for preserving the rights and liabilities of parties to previous federal court decisions by declaring that they could be enforced as if they were rights arising under Supreme Court judgments. The legislation also provided a mechanism for the transfer of pending proceedings to the Supreme Court and for determining the parties' rights and liabilities (particularly having regard to any relevant limitation law) on the deemed basis that the proceedings had originally been commenced in the Supreme Court.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 44.3] r 44.3 Mode of application (cf SCR Part 74, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Mode of application (cf SCR Part 74, rule 5)

p.text: If an application for the transfer of proceedings pending in the Supreme Court is made by the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth, or of a State or Territory under the relevant cross-vesting Act, the Attorney-General does not, by reason of the application, become a party to those proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 44.5] r 44.5 Application relating to transfer (cf SCR Part 74, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Application relating to transfer (cf SCR Part 74, rule 8)

p.text: If a party to any proceedings in the Supreme Court intends to contend that:
the Court should exercise jurisdiction pursuant to any provision of a cross-vesting Act or of any other law of the Commonwealth or a State relating to cross-vesting of jurisdiction, or
that the Court should transfer the proceedings to another Court pursuant to any such provision,

the party must, on or as soon as practicable after commencement of the proceedings, apply to the Court for a determination of the question whether or not the proceedings should be transferred to another Court.
Legislation cited in [44.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 s 5.

Under s 5 of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-Vesting) Act 1987, the court has a wide power to transfer proceedings whenever it is satisfied that the “interests of justice” render another court a “more appropriate” forum. These statutory criteria are inherently general and involve an essentially administrative decision made in the interests of justice: Bankinvest AG v Seabrook (1988) 14 NSWLR 711; 90 ALR 407 per Street CJ. They distinguish the power conferred by the cross-vesting legislation from the court’s more circumscribed power to stay proceedings in cases of forum non conveniens: see James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Barry (2000) 50 NSWLR 357; [2000] NSWCA 353; BC200007474 . “Interests of justice” concern those of both parties and not the selection of the most advantageous or least disadvantageous forum for one of them. The “interests of justice” should be judged by objective factors (see [44.5.20] below). Sometimes consideration of the relevant factors will identify a “natural forum” : BHP Billiton Ltd v Schultz (2004) 221 CLR 400; 211 ALR 523; [2004] HCA 61; BC200408297 (proceedings transferred from NSW to South Australia — “natural forum” — lex loci delicti in South Australia, most of the witnesses from SA).

There are several statements to the effect that there is no onus on the party seeking transfer of proceedings under the cross-vesting legislation: Bankinvest AG v Seabrook (1988) 14 NSWLR 711; 90 ALR 407 per Street CJ and Rogers AJA; see also Australian Consolidated Investments Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1991) 5 ACSR 233 (per Rolfe J); Midland Montague Australia Ltd v O'Connor (1991) 109 FLR 285; Re Chapman & Jansen (1990) 100 FLR 66 at 81 ; Linter Group (in liq) v Price Waterhouse (1992) 9 ACSR 346 ; Arrowcrest Group Pty Ltd v Advertiser News Weekend Publishing Co Pty Ltd (1993) 113 FLR 57 at 61 . However, it is probably more accurate to say that, while questions of onus are unlikely to be decisive in any particular case, the moving party at least bears a persuasive onus of showing that transfer of the proceedings is appropriate in all the circumstances: James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Barry (2000) 50 NSWLR 357; [2000] NSWCA 353; BC200007474 ; Livestock Transport (Sydney) Pty Ltd v Commonwealth [2011] NSWSC 283; BC201102202 at [17] (application to transfer proceedings to Supreme Court of Queensland — similar claim, different party — not in the interests of justice — application refused).

level.toc-caption: [44.5.15] No presumption in favour of the existing forum

heading.title: No presumption in favour of the existing forum

p.text: There is no presumption that the court whose jurisdiction has been invoked should exercise that jurisdiction: see also Midland Montague Australia Ltd v O’Connor (1991) 109 FLR 285 at 293; Chapman v Jansen (1990) 100 FLR 66 at 81 ; Harrison v Trewhella (1994) 122 FLR 90 at 98; 13 WAR 394; BC9401940 ; Linter Group (in liq) v Price Waterhouse (1992) 9 ACSR 346 ; Nilsen Electric (WA) Pty Ltd v Jovista Pty Ltd ACN 009171420 (t/as SDR Construction) (VSC, Byrne J, 8 March 1995, unreported, BC9503233); Junemill Ltd (in liq) v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd (VSC, Hayne J, No 2172/93, 23 February 1994, unreported, BC9405107).

The width of the statutory criteria for transfer under the cross-vesting legislation is similar to the liberal “forum non conveniens” test applied in England. That test, with its emphasis on considerations of fairness and convenience in choosing the more appropriate forum for the conduct of the proceedings: see Spiliada Maritime Corp v Cansulex Ltd [1987] AC 460; [1986] 3 All ER 843 ; broadly corresponds with the criteria in the cross-vesting legislation: see (1988) 62 ALJ 1016. Relevant matters include:

the place where parties reside or carry on business (especially the place of residence of the defendant: BHP Billiton Ltd v Schultz (2004) 221 CLR 400; 211 ALR 523; [2004] HCA 61; BC200408297 at [19] ); British American Tobacco Australia Ltd v Gordon [2007] NSWSC 230; BC200701619 at [69], [70], [79] ; Amaca Pty Ltd v Mundy [2008] NSWSC 604; BC200804448 (transfer from DDT to NSWSC to SASC — defendant resident and previously employed in SA, all witnesses in SA, employer a statutory corporation in SA);
the location of the subject matter of the dispute;
the importance of local knowledge to the resolution of the issues;

the law governing the relevant transaction (especially if the matter involves the construction of state legislation): Australian Consolidated Investments Ltd v Westpac Banking Corp (1991) 5 ACSR 233 ; National Dairies (WA) Ltd v Wesfarmers Ltd (FCA, Tamberlin J, 22 July 1996, unreported, BC9603177); Amaca Pty Ltd v Mundy [2008] NSWSC 604; BC200804448 (transfer from DDT to NSWSC to SASC — new legislation in SA);
the procedures to be adopted (including the facility of reference to a referee: Trade Practices Commission v Collings Construction Co Pty Ltd (1994) 53 FCR 137; 130 ALR 115 );
the likely hearing date: Bourke v State Bank of New South Wales (1988) 22 FCR 378 at 394; 85 ALR 61 ;
whether it is sought to transfer the proceedings to a court with special jurisdiction, for example, the Family Court: Lambert v Dean (1989) Fam LR 285; 97 FLR 352;

location and availability of witnesses; BHP Billiton Ltd v Schultz (2004) 221 CLR 400; 211 ALR 523; [2004] HCA 61; BC200408297 (proceedings transferred from NSW to South Australia — “natural forum” — lex loci delicti in South Australia, most of the witnesses from SA); including the availability and suitability of video link facilities to obviate witnesses’ need to travel to another State: Techtronic Industries Pty Ltd v Mitre 10 Australia Ltd [2008] NSWSC 740; BC200806668 at [9] (transfer application dismissed — availability of video link evidence — no determinative balance of convenience); Professional Advantage Pty Ltd v Smart [2008] NSWSC 873; BC200807658 at [34] (transfer application granted — availability of video link evidence insufficient where other factors pointed to the convenience of the transfer forum);

where one court can resolve the whole controversy without duplication of evidence and issues: Valceski v Valceski (2007) 70 NSWLR 36; 210 FLR 387; [2007] NSWSC 440; BC200703256 (transfer of equity proceedings from NSWSC to Family Court where matrimonial proceedings already on foot); Dye v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [2010] NSWSC 1237; BC201010735 at [28] and [2010] NSWSC 1238; BC201010736 at [5] (NSW defamation proceedings — concurrent FCA unfair dismissal proceedings — related defendants and subject matter);

the location of the tort or wrong: James Hardie & Co Pty Ltd v Barry (2000) 50 NSWLR 357; [2000] NSWCA 353; BC200007474 at [7] ; BHP Billiton Ltd v Schultz (2004) 221 CLR 400; 211 ALR 523; [2004] HCA 61; BC200408297 at [165] per Kirby J; Goldamere Pty Ltd v Metso Minerals Industries Inc [2007] NSWSC 980; BC200707858 at [12] (fire occurred in Tasmania — repair work carried out in Tasmania — Supreme Court of Tasmania the appropriate forum).

Cases of multiple claims in different jurisdictions by unrelated parties against a common defendant raise particular difficulties. Although the wider interests of justice must be considered, the interests of justice also include the interests of the individual plaintiffs in each case: Livestock Transport (Sydney) Pty Ltd v Commonwealth [2011] NSWSC 283; BC201102202 (application for transfer to Supreme Court of Queensland where Commonwealth faced similar claim at suit of different party — common questions of law — additional expense and inconvenience for plaintiff if transferred — application refused).

An exclusive jurisdiction clause nominating the courts of a particular state as the forum for the resolution of disputes between the parties is a significant, but not determinative, factor on a cross-vesting application: West’s Process Engineering Pty Ltd (admin apptd) v Westralian Sands Ltd (NSWSC, Rolfe J, No 50147/97, 6 August 1997, unreported, BC9703418); Air Attention WA v Seeley International Pty Ltd (WASC, Walsh J, No 1479/96, 3 September 1996, unreported, BC9604200); Power and Water Authority v McMahon Contractors Pty Ltd (NTSC, Angel J, 21 September 1995, unreported) cf Nilsen Electric (WA) Pty Ltd v Jovista Pty Ltd (VSC, Byrne J, 8 March 1995, unreported, BC9503233); Goldamere Pty Ltd v Metso Minerals Industries Inc [2007] NSWSC 980; BC200707858 (contracts provided for the laws of NSW to apply and NSWSC to have jurisdiction — Tasmania clearly the appropriate forum on the facts — Tasmanian court can inform itself as to difference between relevant laws in NSW and Tasmania).
Legislation cited in [44.5.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010.

Where proceedings in a Supreme Court involve essentially a contract dispute, it is likely that the interests of justice will require the proceedings remain in the state court, unless there is some significant federal element in the dispute or some other special consideration, such as limitation on the remedies available in the state court. The mere fact that the proceedings involve a claim under the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) (now the Competition and Consumer Act 2010) does not indicate the presence of a significant federal element: Glowtide Pty Ltd v Oceanic Life Ltd (1996) 19 ACSR 471 .
Legislation cited in [44.5.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Limitation Act 1969 s 78.

The cross-vesting legislation was obviously not intended to facilitate “forum shopping” where parties seek to derive advantages from the procedural or substantive law of a particular forum: Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 96 FLR 145 ; Staples v McCall (1989) 98 FLR 152 at 157 ; Chapman v Jansen (1990) 100 FLR 66 at 80 . Prior to the 1993 introduction of s 78 of the Limitation Act 1969 (which characterised limitation laws as substantive laws) this general proposition had led to differences of approach where a potential limitation defence was available in one or other forum. The existence of such a potential defence in the state to which it is sought to be transferred was held to be an irrelevant consideration in Taylor v Trustees of the Christian Brothers (1994) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-288, see also Jenkins v Australian Shipping Commission (NSWSC, Loveday J, 13 September 1991, unreported). On the other hand, it was regarded as a relevant consideration against transfer in Newton v Queensdown Pty Ltd (Sully J, 7 May 1993, unreported); Magian v Mount Isa Mines Ltd (QSC, Studdert J, 31 August 1993, unreported) and DJ v Trustees of the Christian Brothers (15 December 1994, unreported) per Levine J; National Employers Mutual General Insurance Assn Ltd v Nabalco Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Rogers CJ, 1 August 1989, unreported, BC8901895) — though the latter cases might require qualification in light of Brisbane South Regional Health Authority v Taylor (1996) 186 CLR 541; 139 ALR 1 .
Legislation cited in [44.5.40] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 s 52.

The court may transfer part of the proceedings constituted by separate causes of action: Jackson v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1988) 96 FLR 145 (claim for damages under Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth) s 52 transferred, but defamation claim not transferred). However, there is no power to transfer only a part of a cause of action: Blake v Norris (1990) 20 NSWLR 300 (question of liability for negligence could not be transferred, separately from the question of damages).

level.toc-caption: [44.5.45] Removal of proceedings to the Supreme court to permit cross vesting

p.text: Legislation cited in [44.5.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 s 8.

heading.title: Removal of proceedings to the Supreme court to permit cross vesting

p.text: Proceedings commenced in the Industrial Relations Court of New South Wales may be removed into the Supreme Court pursuant to s 8 of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987 and then cross-vested to another state or territory court: Winron Pty Ltd v Shell Co of Australia Ltd (1996) 66 IR 64 (transferring proceedings to the Federal Court prior to the decision in Re Wakim; Ex parte McNally (1999) 198 CLR 511; 163 ALR 270; 31 ACSR 99 ); Tryam Pty Ltd v Grainco Australia Ltd [2003] NSWSC 812; BC200305080 (transfer of proceedings to the Supreme Court of Queensland). Where such a transfer application is made, it will not normally be appropriate for the court to evaluate the merits of the substantive proceedings. But satisfaction that the claim is without merit may afford a basis for refusing to transfer the proceedings: Tryam, above, at [20]–[21] (challenge to the jurisdiction of the Industrial Commission).

The transferring court’s ordinary costs powers (under CPA s 98) permit it to make orders for the costs of the proceedings up to the time of the transfer order (including the costs of the transfer application): Dye v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [2012] NSWCA 220; BC201205505 at [51] . If the transferring court does not make such an order, those costs may be determined by the court to which the proceedings have been transferred: Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross Vesting) Act 1987 s 12.

The prohibition on appeals from a decision “in relation to the transfer” of proceedings (see s 13(a) of the : Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross Vesting) Act 1987) is unlikely to preclude appeals from orders for the costs of the proceedings, other than (potentially) the costs of the transfer application itself: Dye v Commonwealth Bank of Australia [2012] NSWCA 220; BC201205505 at [5], [6], [42], [43], [68] and cf [70].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 44.6] r 44.6 Application of other laws or rules (cf SCR Part 74, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Application of other laws or rules (cf SCR Part 74, rule 9)

p.text: Where a party wishes to contend that the Supreme Court should, under section 11(1)(b) or (c) of the relevant cross-vesting Act, apply the written law of another State or Territory or the rules of evidence or procedure other than those applied in New South Wales, the party must, as soon as practicable:
file notice of the contention, specifying the law or rules and stating the grounds relied upon in support of the contention, and
forthwith after filing the notice, serve it on each other party.

The Supreme Court may, on the application of a party to the proceedings or of its own motion, give directions in relation to the application of a law or rule under section 11(1)(b) or (c) of the relevant cross-vesting Act.
